Award.AwardTitle: Unipolar n-Type Semiconducting Polymers: Synthesis, Electron Transport, and Use in All-Polymer Solar Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

There is a major societal need for novel materials and devices that could potentially render solar energy conversion technologies cost-competitive with fossil fuels. Solar cells made of the polymeric materials to be investigated in this project offer the potential to be more thermally, chemically and photochemically rugged, cheaper, and more readily manufacturable on a large scale compared to the currently more widely studied polymer/fullerene counterparts. The PI and his group will create the building blocks for these materials, study their structures and properties, and fabricate solar cells made of these new materials for investigation of their electronic properties and performance. In addition to the potential technological impacts of this project, other broader impacts will include: (1) educating graduate and undergraduate students in the field of materials for energy technologies; (2) developing and improving curricula by integrating the results of this project into courses for graduate and undergraduate students; (3) disseminating the project results through journal publications, conference presentations, and fostering cross-fertilization of ideas on solar energy among various disciplines through organization of symposia; and (4) partnering with the Pacific Science Center (PSC) of Seattle to bring interactive exhibits on solar energy and plastic materials to the general public. The PI will continue and expand his long-standing involvement of women and minority students in his research program.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The overall goal of this project is to synthesize and investigate new unipolar n-type semiconducting polymers with high electron mobility, a range of energy levels, high crystallinity, and high molecular weights suitable for use as the electron acceptor component in highly efficient all-polymer bulk heterojunction solar cells. The planned research has three interrelated scientific objectives: (i) design, synthesize, and develop new unipolar electron-accepting (n-type) conjugated polymer semiconductors based on naphthalene diimide (NDI) building blocks and recently discovered benzofluoroanthene diimide (BFI) building blocks; (ii) investigate the bulk and field-effect electron transport properties of the new acceptor semiconducting polymers by means of organic field-effect transistor and space charge limited current (SCLC) techniques; and (iii) fabricate all-polymer BHJ solar cells incorporating the new acceptor polymers and investigate their nanoscale morphology, photovoltaic and charge transport properties, and underlying structure-property-device performance relationships. Among the questions to be explored are: Can soluble n-type polymer semiconductors be developed that rival or surpass the widely studied fullerenes in photovoltaic performance? How similar or different are the device efficiency loss mechanisms in all-polymer solar cells versus polymer/fullerene systems? Uncovering the answers to these questions will produce basic new physical insights to underpin the advancement of low-cost organic photovoltaics. Graduate students will be engaged in all facets of the proposed research, enabling the integration of the educational and research programs of the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the most important scientific and technological challenges facing society is finding a way to meet the energy needs of the world’s growing population through an environmentally and economically sustainable paradigm. Polymer solar cells are being researched world-wide because of their great potential to contribute to realizing low-cost photovoltaic power generation technologies. Since they were discovered in 1992, current polymer solar cells have been made by blending an electron-donating polymer and an electron-accepting fullerene material. Electron-accepting polymers have been long sought to overcome the poor stability, high cost and small photovoltage of fullerene-based polymer solar cells.    

The overall goal of this project was to synthesize and investigate new electron-accepting (n-type) semiconducting polymers with a range of suitable properties for use in developing highly efficient all-polymer solar cells. The scientific objectives were: design, synthesize, and develop new n-type polymer semiconductors; investigate the bulk and field-effect electron transport properties of the new semiconducting polymers; and fabricate and evaluate polymer solar cells incorporating the new n-type polymers and investigate their nanoscale morphology, photovoltaic and charge transport properties, and underlying structure-property-device performance relationships.         

We have tested the hypothesis that bulk crystallinity of the polymer components in all-polymer solar cells is a critical factor that determines compatibility, blend morphology, and performance of bulk heterojunction solar cells by synthesis and evaluation of a series of new n-type semiconducting random copolymers, xPDI (10PDI, 30PDI, 50PDI), whose crystallinity varies with composition (Figure 1). The results established for the first time, that the crystallinity of a polymer component and the compatibility, blend morphology, bulk carrier mobilities, and efficiency of polymer/polymer blend solar cells can be controlled by molecular design and specifically by random copolymerization. These results have established random copolymerization as a novel strategy of controlling the crystallinity of semiconducting polymer components of organic solar cells and provided a better understanding of the role of polymer crystallinity on blend compatibility, blend morphology and efficiency of polymer solar cells.

Our group has capitalized on the n-type semiconducting polymers synthesized in this project and systematic studies of their pairing with suitable electron-donating (p-type semiconducting) polymers, resulting in a major breakthrough in developing high performance all-polymer solar cells with record 8 % power conversion efficiency, record short-circuit current density and very high external quantum efficiency. These all-polymer solar cells represent a major milestone in the field of organic photovoltaic science and technology. The results show that charge photogeneration and extraction in all-polymer solar cells can be as efficient as in the more widely studied fullerene/polymer systems. A paper reporting these results was published in Advanced Materials in July 2015 and has already been highly cited (200 citations in Google Scholar) and labeled a HOT Paper by Web of Science.

The scientific and technical advances made in this project have be documented in peer-reviewed publications and many invited presentations at international conferences and seminars presented at other universities. To date, a cumulative total of 7 journal articles have been published based on the research results of this project. Among invited lectures presented include those at: International Summer School on Organic Electronics, Biarritz, France; Next Generation Organic Photovoltaics II, Groningen, the Netherlands; 12th International Symposium on Functional π-Electron Systems (Fπ-12), Seattle; and Distinguished Seminar Series, Imperial College London, Department of Chemical Engineering, London, United Kingdom.

Among the broader impact activities enabled by this project include the service of the PI as a Scientific Editor of Molecular Systems Design and Engineering, a journal published jointly by the Royal Society of Chemistry and Institution of Chemical Engineers (IChemE) in the area of molecular engineering. Our lab hosted a visiting scholar, Assistant Professor Daiki Kazuhara of Graduate School of Materials Science, Nara Institute of Science and Technology (NAIST), Japan, for a year and he participated in the research efforts of the project to synthesize and develop n-type semiconducting polymers.

The funding of this project has enabled the direct training of a total of 5 graduate students in chemistry and chemical engineering. Of these graduate students, one has completed her PhD degree and one has completed his MS degree while the remaining are at various stages of completing their degrees (Figure 2). This project involved the synthesis and characterization of the structural, optical and charge transport properties of polymer semiconductors as well as the fabrication and evaluation of photovoltaic cells. The graduate students involved have had the opportunity to develop research skills and expertise in these areas.
